title: Kaimana Hila
text:
Kaimana Hila is a Hawaiian song composed in 1916 by <a href="Charles%20E.%20King">Charles E. King</a>, assisted by Andrew Cummings, about <a href="Diamond%20Head%2C%20Hawaii">Diamond Head</a>, which can be viewed from <a href="Waikiki">Waikiki beach</a> on <a href="Honolulu">Honolulu</a>, <a href="Oahu">Oahu Island</a>.
Kaimana Hila means Diamond head, from the <a href="Hawaiian%20language">Hawaiian</a> word "Kaimana", which means <a href="diamond">diamond</a>, and the English word <a href="hill">hill</a>. It is one of the popular Hawaiian songs, like <a href="Aloha%20Oe">Aloha Oe</a>, <a href="On%20a%20Little%20Bamboo%20Bridge">On a Little Bamboo Bridge</a>, <a href="Blue%20Hawaii">Blue Hawaii</a>, and King's other song, the <a href="Hawaiian%20Wedding%20Song">Hawaiian Wedding Song</a>.
It is extremely popular in <a href="Japan">Japan</a>, because of the imagery Diamond head from Waikiki, Honolulu, the Japanese people's most popular tourist destination in Hawaii.
The music is melodious and easy to remember. The words start with the following lines:
